docs.lead_paragraph: As Republicans and Democrats claim to be searching for common ground in the health care debate, one idea that lawmakers on both sides seem to agree on is that health insurance should be sold across state lines. Republicans like Representative John Shadegg of Arizona have long called for this change, saying it would increase competition among health insurers and provide consumers with a greater array of choices.

headline.main: Let Health Insurance Cross State Lines, Some Say

docs.abstract: Republicans and Democrats seem to agree that letting health insurance companies sell policies across state lines would increase competition and could lower costs, but disagree over how to allow such sales; some experts are also concerned that allowing healthier adults to buy out-of-state policies would drive up costs for less-healthy people in states where law requires more comprehensive coverage; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As Republicans and Democrats claim to be searching for common ground in the health care debate, one idea that lawmakers on both sides seem to agree on is that health insurance should be sold across state lines.     Republicans like Representative...

docs.lead_paragraph: SEEKING to stimulate the nation's moribund economy, Congress offered Americans a variety of tax-based incentives to spend money and to help cope with daily living last year. Among them are new or expanded credits for home purchases, energy-efficient home improvements and college costs; the making-work-pay credit; and the right to enhance the standard deduction with additional deductions for real estate taxes and sales taxes on purchases of new vehicles. The breaks will please many taxpayers, and using tax software can ease the complications they may bring to preparing a return. To help taxpayers understand the changes and claim all the breaks to which they are entitled, Jan M. Rosen of The New York Times prepared a sample return for a hypothetical New York suburban couple. She used the TurboTax program, published by Intuit, in consultation with Bob Meighan, vice president of TurboTax.

docs.lead_paragraph: How much does care for illegal immigrants cost? The subject is an emotional one. Tensions were evident last fall when Representative Joe Wilson, Republican of South Carolina, shouted ''You lie!'' after President Obama, in a speech before Congress, denied that illegal immigrants would receive free coverage under the Democrats' proposed health care legislation.
